requirements.notes: The International Business and Culture requirement may be satisfied with INTL 201 or any other approved internationally-focused business course. 1 In or outside the School of Business.

courses: Six units of upper-division Business Administration or Economics courses. All courses must be at the 300- or 400-level (unless a 200-level course is required for a current School of Business Minor, with a maximum of one 200-level course) with at least two units at the 400-level. Within the six units, three units must be in one discipline. The remaining units must consist of courses from at least two different disciplines in the School of Business.
requirements.notes: No more than one unit may be an internship or international travel experience course. No more than one unit may be an independent study.

eligibility: Available to undergraduates in the College of Arts and Sciences and the School of Music.

courses: SOBA 201 - Fundamentals of Financial Analysis (1 unit)
SOBA 202 - Fundamentals of Organizations and Markets (1 unit)
SOBA 203 - Fundamentals of Marketing and Technology (1 unit)

description: A FLEX major is a special interdisciplinary business major designed by the student in collaboration with an advisor. It allows highly performing and self-directed students to pursue the course of study that they are most passionate about.
eligibilityRequirements: Students must have completed at least 12 units, including 8 units at Stetson, and have a GPA of at least 3.30. Intent to double major must be declared and approved during the ILP application process.
applicationProcess: To apply, students must construct an Individualized Learning Plan (ILP) articulating the rationale, learning goals, and coursework. The ILP must also include a plan for assessing the student's progress.
ILPRequirements: Approval by key departments, where appropriate
approvalProcess: The ILP will be presented to an approval committee chosen by the Associate Dean. The committee will discuss the merits of the applicants and ILP to ensure rigor and appropriateness of the proposed curriculum.

majorName: Business Systems and Analytics – Business Systems Management
description: This major focuses on business systems management and analytics, providing students with the skills needed for managing business processes and data-driven decision-making.

majorName: Business Systems and Analytics – Data Analytics
description: This major focuses on data analytics with courses in programming, databases, and various analytics techniques.

requiredCourses: Select one unit from the following: BSAN 323V Health Analytics, BSAN 481 Social Media Analytics, STAT 440Q Forecasting, STAT 460Q Experimental Design and Advanced Data Analysis

courses: SOBA 202 Fundamentals of Organizations and Markets
SOBA 203 Fundamentals of Marketing and Technology
INTL 201 International Business and Culture (or equivalent)

experientialLearning.description: Experiential learning is the process of developing knowledge and skill from direct active experiences beyond a traditional classroom.
requirements: Scope: It must represent a significant investment of time and effort on the part of the student.
Rigor: It must entail a noteworthy interaction with college-level academic thought.
Promote Reflection: It must involve personal application by the student of classroom material.
experientialLearning.preApprovedActivities: Many courses and co-curricular activities are pre-approved as satisfying the experiential learning requirement. Students may also petition for special approval of additional activities.

eligibilityRequirements: The student must complete School of Business General Education Requirements and School of Business Foundation Requirements.
internationalBusinessRequirement: The International Business and Culture requirement may be satisfied with INTL 201 or any other approved internationally-focused business course.

description: This minor provides students with a foundation in business systems analytics, including courses in financial analysis, marketing, and various analytics topics.

requiredCourses: SOBA 203 Fundamentals of Marketing and Technology
electiveCourses: BSAN 323V Health Analytics: Analytics, Informatics and Healthcare
BSAN 351V Technology Globalization and Social Justice
BSAN 390 Special Topics in Business Systems and Analytics
STAT 460Q Experimental Design and Advanced Data Analysis

description: This major explores various aspects of communication and media, including public speaking, communication ethics, interpersonal communication, research methods, and more.

majorRequirements.generalEducationRequirements: The student must complete the General Education Requirements of the College of Arts & Sciences (9 units).
requiredCourses: COMM 200 Introduction to Communication and Media Studies
majorRequirements.generalCommunicationAndMediaStudies: Select two units from the following: COMM 210V Communication and Media Ethics, COMM 216 Argumentation and Debate, COMM 221S Interpersonal Communication, COMM 228S Intercultural Communication (Can be used as a V course), COMM 231 Critical Studies of Mass Media, COMM 241A Visual Communication, COMM 285 Independent Study, COMM 290 Special Topics in Communication Studies, COMM 301 Qualitative Theory and Methodology
majorRequirements.researchMethodsInCommunicationAndMediaSt: Select two units from the following: COMM 301 Qualitative Theory and Methodology, COMM 302 Rhetorical Theory and Criticism, COMM 303 Media Theory and Analysis
majorRequirements.upperDivisionCommunicationAndMediaStudie: Select two units from the following: COMM 311 Classical Rhetoric, COMM 314B Rhetoric, Culture, and Identity, COMM 321V Gender in Communication, COMM 325 Organizational Communication, COMM 327V Health Communication, COMM 328B Food, Communication and Culture, COMM 333 Communication and Technology, COMM 367V Environmental Communication, COMM 385 Independent Study, COMM 390 Special Topics in Communication Studies, COMM 411 Philosophy of Communication, COMM 430B Media, Nation, and (Im)Migration, COMM 444 History and Criticism of American Public Address, COMM 485 Independent Study, COMM 490 Special Topics in Communication Studies
otherRequirements: COMM 397 Internship in Communication and Media Studies

eligibilityRequirements: Students must meet the eligibility criteria set by the institution to pursue a major in Communication and Media Studies.

description: This minor provides students with an understanding of communication and media concepts, including public speaking, communication ethics, research methods, and more.

requirements: COMM 200 Introduction to Communication and Media Studies
generalCommunicationAndMediaStudies: COMM 228S Intercultural Communication (Can be used as a D course)
COMM 231 Critical Studies of Mass Media
COMM 290 Special Topics in Communication Studies
researchMethodsInCommunicationAndMediaSt: Select one unit from the following:
upperDivisionCommunicationAndMediaStudie: Select one unit from the following:
COMM 390 Special Topics in Communication Studies
COMM 444 History and Criticism of American Public Address
COMM 490 Special Topics in Communication Studies *

eligibilityRequirements: Students must meet the eligibility criteria set by the institution to pursue a minor in Communication and Media Studies.

courses.course_title: Special Topics in Computer Information Systems
courses.description: Introductory-level course with varied content. Covers topics not typically taught in existing courses. Content rigor is consistent with second or third-year courses in the department.

Introduction to relational database systems, including requirements gathering, database design, normalization, SQL programming, and NoSQL databases. Offered annually in either fall or spring. Prerequisite: CSCI 111, CSCI 141, or CSCI 261, or permission of instructor.
Faculty-mentored course covering content not addressed by current courses. Typically involves one or two students led by a faculty member.

courses.course_title: Special Topics in Computer Information Systems
courses.description: Course designed by faculty to explore topics not typically covered in existing courses. Content rigor aligns with second or third-year courses in the department.
Focuses on full web application development, covering front-end (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React) and back-end (Node.js). Offered every spring. Prerequisite: CSCI 221.

Introduction to mobile computing and mobile app development. Covers various mobile technologies, software development for mobile platforms, and modern distributed software systems. Offered based on student demand. Prerequisite: CSCI 221.

Focuses on ethical and legal issues related to information technology, including copyright, security, and privacy. Explores the impact of ethical and social issues on IT design and implementation. Offered annually in either fall or spring. Junior Seminar.
Faculty-mentored course for content not covered by current courses. Typically involves one or two students led by a faculty member. May cover third or fourth-year content.

courses.course_title: Special Topics in Computer Information Systems
courses.description: Course designed by faculty to explore topics not typically covered in existing courses. Content rigor aligns with third or fourth-year courses in the department. May be repeated for credit.
Internship with an outside company or organization, emphasizing relevant learning and career skills. Prerequisite: Approval of chair and faculty supervisor.

Survey of acquiring, storing, accessing, and analyzing large data sets. Covers data sources, APIs, distributed systems, databases, and data mining. Offered every spring. Prerequisite: CSCI 221 or permission of instructor.
Faculty-mentored course for content not covered by current courses. Typically involves one or two students led by a faculty member. May cover fourth-year content.

courses.course_title: Special Topics in Computer Information Systems
courses.description: Course designed by faculty to explore topics not typically covered in existing courses. The sophistication and rigor of the content is consistent with courses that are offered in the fourth year of study in the department.

Students will select a topic in computer information systems, work on it with a faculty member, develop a project proposal, and present their findings to the department. Prerequisite: Three CSCI or CINF courses at the 300 level or above. Writing Enhanced course.
An extension of the research project started in CINF 498. Students write a final paper and present their results to the department. Prerequisite: CINF 498. Writing Enhanced course.
